attachments.text: Roger Luo is the 2020 Winner of the Wittek Quantum Prize for Open Source Software for his work on Yao.jl and several other projects. The…
attachments.fallback: Medium: Announcing the Winner of the 2020 Wittek Quantum Prize for Open Source Software

elements.text: for Yao.jl and a ver well deserved prize:

text: This is really something. There is a *lot* of well-funded OSS in python for quantum computing and information.

elements.text: This is really something. There is a
of well-funded OSS in python for quantum computing and information.

text: I hear that more folks at MIT doing quantum computing are using Julia nowadays.

elements.text: I hear that more folks at MIT doing quantum computing are using Julia nowadays.

text: thanks everyone! I’d like to appreciate the Julia community - the Yao and its surrounding packages are not possible without my collaborators (<@UCD4Z3NJZ> and <@UJZRMV12Q> and Pan Zhang) and many other Julians. It is built on the top of many many Julians’ work too. And  I believe Julia has its unique advantage comparing to other platforms, it will power quantum devices in a similar way like how CUDA.jl works at some point and make use of other great piece of work in the community. I’m sure more and more ppl in the quantum community will move to JuliaLang.

thanks everyone! I’d like to appreciate the Julia community - the Yao and its surrounding packages are not possible without my collaborators (

and Pan Zhang) and many other Julians. It is built on the top of many many Julians’ work too. And  I believe Julia has its unique advantage comparing to other platforms, it will power quantum devices in a similar way like how CUDA.jl works at some point and make use of other great piece of work in the community. I’m sure more and more ppl in the quantum community will move to JuliaLang.
